Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

Ormat Recovered Energy Generator: OREG1 CS-10



Description of Corporate Prevention and Emergency Response Approach



This facility complies with numerous standards for pressure vessel design and testing as well as all Federal and South Dakota process safety management requirements. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. Copies of emergency response, process hazard analyses and process safety management plans and all technical drawing (P&IDS) for process equipment are maintained onsite for reference. Regular inspection and testing of the pentane and thermal oil systems are performed to ensure equipment integrity is maintained. The facility is equipped with a network of leak detection equipment, automatic shutdown logic controls, insulation, safety relief valves, fire detection monitors. OREG1 provides high levels of training in operating procedures, safety and emergency response. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to implement the emergency response procedures to mitigate damages, and to notify the nearest fire department and request their assistance. 



Description of Stationary Source 



The OREG1 power units are fueled by waste heat from a compressor turbine exhaust that is transformed from thermal energy into mechanical energy. This is accomplished by utilizing the organic Rankine cycle (ORC) technology. The hot gases of the turbine exhaust flow through a waste Heat Oil Heater (WHOH), where the heat from the gases is transferred to a thermal oil heat transfer fluid. The thermal oil is then circulated to the shell and tube vaporizer of an Ormat Energy Converter (OEC). The motive fluid on the shell side is vaporized and these vapors drive a special organic fluid turbine. This turbine, which rotates at 1800 rpm drives a generator which produces grid compatible power. The motive fluid then passes through a heat exchanger and enters the cycle again as a liquid. After exitin

g the various heat exchangers, the thermal oil passes through the thermal oil surge tanks and the thermal oil feed pumps, which discharge it into the WHOH. The power from this project is sold to Basin Electric Power cooperative based in Bismarck, ND. 



The basic Rankine cycle model consists of four components: 

1.    Pump - Work Input

2.    Boiler - Heat Input

3.    Turbine     - Work output

4.    Condenser - Heat Rejection



The Rankine cycle consists of pressurizing a liquid (pentane), vaporizing the high pressure liquid, expanding the high pressure vapor and condensing the low pressure vapor for reuse. The energy necessary for the vaporization is provided by thermal oil at a maximum temperature of 572A?F. The thermal energy is transferred to the pentane working fluid via tube and counter-current shell heat exchangers. The OREG1 facility uses a commercial pentane with a dry cooling heat rejection system. 



Primary Activities 



Waste thermal energy is converted to electric power. The facility is rated at 6.3MW average. The net power output to the electrical grid is rated at 5.4 MW average.  Power output is reduced in warm weather due to limitations of the air cooled heat exchangers. 



Use of regulated substance 



Pentane, a flammable vapor/liquid is used as a binary working fluid.  Liquid pentane is pumped from a condenser to shell and tube heat exchangers. Thermal energy provided by thermal oil is transferred to the pentane. The thermal oil heat input causes the pentane to change physical states from liquid to high pressure superheated vapor that is passed through a turbine to produce electric power. The vapor is condensed and recycled back to a pressurized liquid recuperator vessel to complete the Rankine cycle. A pentane storage tank is available for makeup. The facility design is segregated into multiple sections, each having its own design specifications dictated by the pentane conditions in that section. The sections include: the low pressure process equipmen

t, the high pressure process equipment, pentane unloading system, vapor recovery system, evacuation system and non-condensable removal system. Each section is protected by pressure relief systems that may include pressure safety valves, pressure control valves, control system shutdown and intervention logic and administrative practices. 



Quantities Handled or Stored 



The pentane is normally found in both the operating and static portions of the process.  When in operation, the majority of the pentane is found in the working binary process.  There is some additional pentane present in the connected storage tank.  For the purpose of defining registration quantities, a fully-charged operating system is assumed plus a storage tank that contains the residual amount of pentane.  For the purpose of calculating a registration quantity, the 28,000 metric tons (61,728 lbs) shipped to the site for the initial fill is used.



Worst Case Scenario 



Worst case scenario is based on a vapor cloud explosion. Although safeguards are in place to make a worst case scenario extremely unlikely, it was assumed the explosion originates at a full pentane storage tank, which represents the largest single container onsite.  The tank is assumed to be filled to 80% of water capacity.

The RMP comp model is a conservative screening tool and may overestimate distances to endpoint. By RMP rules,

the model does not accommodate mitigative measures that may prevent propagation of any accident.

 



OREG1 CS-10 is located in a relatively isolated area surrounded by farmland. The facility is approximately 5 km south of Crocker, SD.  Examination of topographic maps and visual observation of the potentially affected area in a worst case scenario did identify one (1) residential structure with total occupancy of four (4), but no parks or other public places.  In addition, this facility is adjacent to the compressor station that provides the heat source and this station is within the affected area.  The compressor station staff is not employed by Ormat, nor does Ormat control their access to the compressor station.  Given this proximity to public receptors, this facility cannot qualify for an RMP program level 1.  



Alternate Case Scenario Description



The alternate case scenario is based on a pool fire.  The pool is formed upon a hose rupture that occurs during tanker truck offloading to the pentane storage tank.  It is very conservatively assumed that it takes approximately 10 minutes to stop the flow.

Prevention Program Description 



Safety information: 



Maintenance Procedures: OREG1 has installed and operates a computerized maintenance Management software (CMMS) program. This CMMS contains information on all equipment in the facility

requiring maintenance, inspections, testing, certification, calibration, etc. NFPA, OSHA, manufacturer's recommendations and operations experience have been utilized to produce a comprehensive maintenance work order system that produces maintenance requests at appropriate frequencies. Employees report any equipment deficiencies to the operation and maintenance manager who generates "work orders" for the repair or assessment of the problem. Routine comprehensive inspections are performed using checklists. 



Emergency Response Plan: The emergency response plan is intended to identify and coordinate personnel in the event there is an emergency. 



Training: Some equipment in the OREG1 facilities poses potential fire, explosion, and electrical hazards that could cause serious personal injuries and costly property damage if safety procedures are not followed correctly. Safety training, conducted monthly and required of all employees, identifies the different hazards to be found on the sites. These subjects include electrical safety, fire prevention and protection, lock out and tag out procedures, hazard communication, gas detectors, fire panels, personal protective equipment, and the safe use of tools and equipment. Safety training is supplemented by the use of the Industrial Hygiene and Standard Safety Procedures manuals. 



Call out Procedure: If any of the following Alarm conditions are indicated by the OREG1 monitoring system, this call-out procedure must be followed: OEC failure, OEC low output, security/fire alarm trip. If any of these events should occur the monitoring staff will immediately contact the operation and maintenance manager. If the operation and maintenance manager is not reached in a timely manner the parent company, Ormat Nevada Inc. will be notified on the 24 hour phone number (775)-852-1912. If a fire is detected the monitoring staff shall notify local emergency personnel including fire and police departments. 



Notification of Northern Pip

eline Personnel: Any Northern Border Personnel which may 

be at the site during the alarm condition must also be notified through Northern Border procedures. Northern Border Personnel should not attempt to respond to the alarm conditions unless they have been trained and certified to do so. The principal methods of accident prevention include equipment design safeguards, written procedures and operator/employee training. Safety systems are present in the facilities and have various methods of operation. Pressure safety systems typically have three levels of degree. The initial degree is an alarm that is presented audibly and visually to the control Room operator. The 

next more severe degree is a shutdown of process equipment likely to be causing or exacerbating the condition and an alarm that is presented audibly and visually to the control Room operator. The third and most severe degree of pressure safety system are Pressure safety valves which relieve to atmosphere or to larger low pressure systems. Some of these PSV's also have control Room Alarms. A combustible gas detection system is present in each of the plants.  Sensors are strategically located in each plant control Room audio and visual alarms annunciate concentrations in excess of 40% of LEL. 



Process Hazard Analysis 

OREG1 utilized a professional safety consultant experienced in organic Rankine power cycles to perform a hazard analysis appropriate to the complexity of the process for identifying, evaluating, and controlling hazards involved in the process and shall determine and document the priority order for conducting process hazard analyses based on the extent of process hazards, number of potentially affected employees, age of the process and process operating history. A HAZOP analysis was selected and utilized.  



The original process hazard analysis was revalidated in August, 2009.



Accident History 

OREG1 CS-10 has not had any reportable accidents. 



Emergency Response Plan 

OREG's

Emergency Response is based on recognition and observation of potential emergency conditions, and immediate repair, or notification of the primary response agency. The policy for emergency response at OREG1 is to mitigate any accident by implementing emergency procedures that have been developed for all known contingencies. Small fires will be contained and mitigated with fire extinguishing equipment and automatic suppression systems. Emergency notification is required for 

any release or threatened release of a hazardous material which poses a significant present or potential health, safety or environmental hazard. The O&M manager is designated incident command when present. The senior operator is designated incident command when management is not present. Incident command is transferred to emergency responders upon arrival.
